### Prerequisites

We recommend that readers consult the sections **Understanding text** and **First steps** to gain a deeper understanding of the summarized information presented in this text (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

### What is an Atlas?

This section of *History Tracers* brings together various maps. When we have this type of organized collection, we call it an atlas (<htcite0>).

### Introduction

Before we talk about our planet and the divisions we have created, let us explore what we know about how nature formed the structures we recognize today.

#### An interdisciplinary atlas?

Yes! The areas of knowledge are interconnected. That is why we include different disciplines to help you better understand how the world works.

#### A Law In his classes on the History of Asia, Dr. Abdul Karim Khan presents a fundamental relationship between History and Geography: *"...if History has any laws, Geography is the first law"* (). Based on this definition, it becomes essential to study the evolution of the continents and of our species from this perspective. #### Stages of learning In school, we are introduced to subjects such as Science or Geography even before entering university. However, teaching often limits itself to showing only the initial stages of this field. These stages could be called proto-Geography or pre-Geography, as proposed by Dr. Francisco González A. Redondo (; ; ).

In the texts of this section, we present the concepts of pre-Geography and proto-Geography, gradually connecting them to Geography through mathematics.

### The Origin of the Universe

The image in this section represents our understanding of the history of the universe according to the Lambda-CDM model (<htcite0>).

#### Our Initial Explanations

The origin of the universe is something that humanity has been trying to explain for millennia.

Various models have been created by human beings to explain the creation of the “sky” and the Earth, many of which were centered on humanity — that is, they were anthropocentric (<htcite1>):
- Around <htdate0>, the Babylonians described the creation of humankind in the **Epic of Atrahasis**. They also narrated a great divine punishment through a flood, from which only Atrahasis survived (<htcite2>; <htcite3>; <htcite4>; <htcite5>).
- Although the **Popol Vuh** was written in Mesoamerica (*Abya Yala*) between <htdate1> and <htdate2> (<htcite6>), murals found in El Mirador and Izapa, dated to around <htdate3>, show that the beliefs recorded in the Popol Vuh already existed in the region long before it was written (<htcite7>).

Although humanity created other epic texts — some influenced by these — (<htcite8>; <htcite9>), we will limit ourselves to these two in this Atlas.

Reflection: On Texts and Data

Descriptions of a universe created for humankind contrast with measurements made in different fields of science.

Does that mean ancient epics are wrong?

#### Literature and Sciences

There is much confusion around the idea that literature (epics and poems) cannot be related to the sciences.

This misconception is deepened by the fact that literary texts are often classified imprecisely.

To help clarify these topics, History Tracers is developing the section *Understanding Texts* (<htcite0>), where we explore in greater depth the relationship between science and literature (<htcite1>), examining, among other things, the boundaries between poetry and fact (<htcite2>).

When we restrict ourselves to labeling something as “right” or “wrong,” we often overlook the complexity of texts in favor of convenience or simplicity (<htcite3>; <htcite4>; <htcite5>). A thorough analysis of scientific data and literary works can reveal that both can be correct within their respective contexts.

#### What Do We Really Know?

The evolution of knowledge about the structure of the universe is relatively recent, with major advances occurring from the 20th century onward (<htcite0>), according to the Gregorian calendar.

Among the many discoveries that expanded our understanding of the cosmos, two stand out for helping us comprehend how the planet we live on was formed:
- Edwin Hubble’s discovery that the universe is expanding (<htcite1>);
- The discovery of the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation, the oldest information we have ever measured from the universe (<htcite2>).

These findings are represented in the image above and will be further detailed in the upcoming texts of this section of the *Atlas*.

### The Big Bang

The image in this section represents our current understanding of the history of the universe according to the Lambda-CDM model (<htcite0>).

#### The First Ideas

Our early conception of the universe did not include an expanding cosmos — the original models considered it static (<htcite1>).

However, discoveries made by Edwin Hubble (<htcite2>) showed that this view did not match the observational data, and thus it needed to be revised.

Reflection: What Now?

Imagine you are a scientist living in , when Hubble discovered that the universe is expanding. How would you react?

a) You would say that all scientific models are wrong.
b) You would do nothing, waiting for others to research it.
c) You would try to understand the new data and propose models that better explain the universe.

Different scientists responded in different ways — and some of these responses actually appeared before Hubble’s discovery (<htcite0>):
- In <htdate0>, Alexander Friedmann demonstrated that Einstein’s equations allowed for a dynamic, expanding universe.
- In <htdate1>, Georges Lemaître independently proposed that the universe was expanding, though not exactly in the way we understand it today.

Even though these works were published before Hubble’s measurements, they were largely ignored until the <htdate2>s.

#### Different Views

Our understanding of the universe advanced when, on <htdate3>, George Gamow proposed that the universe began from an extremely dense and hot primordial gas (<htcite1>; <htcite2>).

Alongside the idea of a beginning that evolved into the universe we see today, the steady-state theory also emerged. According to this theory, although the universe is expanding, its average density remains constant. Thus, it would have neither a beginning nor an end (<htcite3>; <htcite4>).

These different ideas, in an unusual twist, ended up giving a name to the model we use today.

On <htdate4>, during a BBC interview about the steady-state theory, Sir Fred Hoyle stated that the other model (then unnamed) was unacceptable — and referred to it three times as the “Big Bang.” That name stuck (<htcite5>).

### How Do We Choose Between Models?

Whenever there are different models explaining natural phenomena, we must determine which one best matches reality.

The only way to know whether a model is correct is through measurements.

In <htdate5>, Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson measured the cosmic microwave background radiation, which we understand to be the leftover light from the early universe (<htcite6>; <htcite7>).

These measurements were incompatible with the steady-state model but perfectly matched the predictions of the Big Bang.

For that reason, the Big Bang model is considered the most accurate explanation of the universe.

source.text: Penzias, A. A., & Wilson, R. W.

Reflection: What Came Before?

The Big Bang model explains the universe we see today — but was there something before it?

### What came first?

The most honest answer we can give is simple: we don’t know.

The oldest information we have about the universe comes from the cosmic microwave background radiation, which dates to about 400,000 years after the universe began — still far from the actual moment of the Big Bang itself (<htcite0>).

Just as there have been different models to explain why the universe is expanding, there are also theories that try to describe its earliest moments (<htcite1>). To choose among them, we need new measurements. And if all of them turn out to be wrong, we can formulate new ones.

In other words, as Socrates taught us, the **only thing we know is that we know nothing** (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

### Cosmic Inflation

The image in this section represents our understanding of the history of the universe according to the Lambda-CDM model. As can be observed, right after the Big Bang there appears a sort of cone — this period is known as **Cosmic Inflation** (<htcite0>).

#### What was the beginning like?

Thanks to Edwin Hubble, we know that the universe is expanding (<htcite1>). As a direct consequence of this discovery, we can conclude that in the past, the universe was much smaller — as shown in **Figure 2**, part of **Practice 1**.

text.text: However, knowing that the universe was smaller doesn’t explain exactly how it expanded. This leads us to a reflection:

Reflection: How did it happen?

How do you think the universe expanded over time?

#### The proposal

Our knowledge of the universe’s size has evolved over the past centuries. We went from an initial estimate of 300,000 light-years in <htdate0> to about 94 billion light-years in <htdate1> (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

It’s not only the universe’s size that draws attention. Another remarkable fact in this cosmic story is that, when we look in different directions, we find that the universe is uniform (<htcite2>).

This beautiful scenario, however, presents a problem described and explained by Alan H. Guth (<htcite3>; <htcite4>), which leads us to reflect further:

Reflection: Why are they the same?

Suppose a signal were sent from two opposite ends of the universe just as it began expanding. We would receive those signals from both ends before one could reach the other. In other words, the ends don’t know each other.

If, after 14 billion years, those opposite ends still cannot exchange information, how can they be so similar?

#### Guth’s solution

Doctor Alan Guth proposed a solution to this problem. At the beginning of the universe, when matter and energy were still unified, there was a monumental expansion in an extremely short period of time — the universe grew in size extremely fast (exponential).

Thus, although the opposite ends have not been in contact for billions of years, there was a time when the universe was homogeneous, and that homogeneity remained after its exponential expansion (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

#### Is there proof?

Science is not made up solely of theories; many ideas are refined to reach a deeper understanding. The same applies to the Inflation Theory, as Doctor Guth himself acknowledged and Doctor Lincoln explained in his video (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

Some experiments suggest that inflation did in fact occur, while others highlight the need for more evidence and further research.

### All Together

The image in this section represents our understanding of the history of the universe according to the Lambda-CDM model. As can be observed, after Cosmic Inflation, the process of formation of the particles we are about to study begins (<htcite0>).

#### Who came first?

Right after Inflation, the first particles began to appear in the universe. To understand them, let's reflect:

Reflection: The universe is like me

The laws of the universe do not change over time. Thus, we can look at our own growth and, from that, propose an analogy with the development of the universe.

We start with the union of our parents' cells and develop inside our mother, forming a baby that is born after gestation. After the baby stage, we become children; then adolescents; and finally, adults.

Would it make sense for the universe to start with large structures already in place, like the Moon, stars, and planets?

Just as we started as small cells until we became who we are, the universe also started small.

#### First Particles

Immediately after the end of Inflation—which lasted less than a second—the first elementary particles began to appear (<htcite0>).

Although particles have existed in the universe for billions of years, our discovery and understanding of them only occurred in the 20th century, according to the Gregorian calendar.

The idea of something indivisible, called the "atom", originated with Democritus, around <htdate0> (<htcite1>).

With advances in knowledge and the development of machines capable of making more precise measurements, we concluded that atomic models like Rutherford's (<htcite2>; <htcite3>), represented in Graph 1, considered only the electron as a fundamental particle (<htcite4>).

Other particles, like protons and neutrons, contained within them even smaller particles, which we now know as quarks (<htcite5>).
Graph 1: Representation of Rutherford model.

#### A Different Matter

Besides the particles that form atoms, during this period there was also antimatter, which, upon contact with the matter we know, annihilates (or eliminates), forming gamma radiation (<htcite0>).

The fact that matter and antimatter annihilate each other made the early universe an extremely turbulent environment. For some reason—which we are still trying to understand—an imbalance occurred as the universe cooled. As a result, we now have more matter than antimatter, although the existence of very distant regions in the universe where antimatter might still exist is not ruled out (<htcite1>).

#### A Non-Visible Matter

Matter and antimatter were not alone in the early universe. There is another type of matter whose composition we still do not know. However, its existence is undeniable, because measurements show that the rotation speed of a spiral galaxy is higher than expected based only on visible matter (<htcite2>).

#### The First Measurements

This stage of the union of different particles—including the photon, the light particle—according to our current models, lasted about 380,000 years (<htcite3>).

This is a period for which we have no direct data to prove our theories; therefore, we conduct experiments to understand what might have happened in that time interval.

From 380,000 years after the Big Bang, we already have observational data—light separated from matter. This first information we obtain from the primordial universe is called the Cosmic Microwave Background, and it is the topic of the next section of the *Atlas*.

### Cosmic Microwave Background

The image in this section shows the Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) recorded by the ESA (European Space Agency) Planck mission (<htcite0>).

#### It is not noise, it is a discovery

In <htdate0>, A. A. Penzias and R. W. Wilson observed that the temperature of a horn reflector antenna remained 3.5 K (Kelvin) higher than expected (<htcite1>).

source.text: Penzias, A. A., & Wilson, R. W.

text.text:
Reflection: What could it be?

When we talk about measuring temperature, we usually think of a thermometer. Imagine that you feel fine, no fever, but when you take your temperature, the thermometer reads 40 °C.

What would you do in that situation?

You would probably suspect that there is something wrong with the thermometer. Similarly, the researchers also tested for potential problems.

While investigating possible measurement errors, Penzias and Wilson ruled out a series of potential causes: atmospheric absorption, impedance, antenna temperature, imperfections in the structure, and even backlobe effects (<htcite0>).

With all instrumental problems eliminated, the need to find a new explanation arose.

### Confirming the Big Bang

The measurements by Penzias and Wilson could not be attributed to any known source in the Universe—such as stars or galaxies (<htcite1>). However, their results matched the predictions presented in another paper, by R. H. Dicke, P. J. E. Peebles, P. G. Roll, and D. T. Wilkinson (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

According to Dicke et al., the early Universe should have had a temperature of about 10 billion Kelvin (10,000,000,000 K), which, throughout the cosmic expansion, would have cooled to approximately 3.5 K—exactly the value observed by Penzias and Wilson (<htcite4>).

This discovery not only confirmed the prediction of the Cosmic Microwave Background but also reinforced the model of a uniform and isotropic Universe—that is, with the same properties in all directions of space (<htcite5>; <htcite6>).

### The Birth of a Star

The image in this section shows a circle highlighting the region of the Milky Way where stellar formations can be seen within red clouds (<htcite0>).

#### The Beginning

The formation of stars is a long and gradual process in the universe. It took around 300 million years for the first stars to appear (<htcite1>).

For a star to be born, a large cloud of cold dust composed mainly of Hydrogen (H) is necessary. From it, stars may form due to gravitational collapse (“matter coming together”) or from the pressure of gas heated by nearby stars (<htcite2>; <htcite3>; <htcite4>).

#### The Collapse of Clouds

Inside these clouds, still cold — with temperatures around -240 ºC (-400 ºF) — nuclei made only of Hydrogen (H) atoms are formed. These nuclei begin to collide, heating the interior and gathering more matter. This process eventually leads to the formation of so-called “baby stars” (<htcite5>; <htcite6>; <htcite7>).

#### The Formation of the Star

As matter collapses into the interior of the protostar, Hydrogen (H) atoms begin to fuse, creating Helium (He) atoms (<htcite8>). As for the dust that does not become part of the star, it tends to clump together, forming what we know as planets (<htcite9>).

This is a general view built from data collected by telescopes. However, since star formation takes thousands of years, the full process has never been observed directly (<htcite10>).

#### Literature

It is not uncommon to find in ancient texts descriptions of stars and people forming almost spontaneously (<htcite11>; <htcite12>; <htcite13>). These accounts cannot be considered wrong, as they belong to the realm of literature. On the other hand, they reveal humanity’s desire to explain the universe—an aspiration that goes back thousands of years (<htcite14>).

### How Is a Planet Formed?

The image in this section shows the disk of a planet in formation. This region is known as **IRAS 04302+2247** and is located 525 light-years from Earth — equivalent to approximately 4.97 quadrillion kilometers (4,966,920,000,000,000 km) away (<htcite0>).

source.text: ESA/Webb, NASA & CSA, M. Villenave et al.

text.text:
Mathematics and Physics in Geography

Have you ever stopped to think about what 525 light-years actually means as a distance?

Since a year is a unit of time, we first need to understand what it represents in this context.
A light-year is the distance that light travels in one year. This means that when we observe something 525 light-years away, we are actually seeing the past (ESA, ), has been traveling for 525 years to reach us.

Knowing that photons traveled without interruption until they reached us, we understand that their journey extended over 525 years, covering the same distance every second. In other words, the same amount of distance is added each year (History Tracers Team, , Adding the same numbers).

Therefore, to calculate the total distance, we simply need to multiply the distance covered in one year by 525.

What Is That Distance?

Light travels at approximately 300,000 km per second.
So we must multiply that value by the number of seconds in a year, and then multiply the result by 525 years.
The simplest way to express this is through multiplication:

525 light-years = years × distance per year
525 light-years = years × (distance per second × seconds per year)
525 light-years = years × [(distance per second) × (seconds per day × days per year)]

Substituting the values, we get:
525 light-years = 525 × [(300000) × (864000 × 365)] = 4.966.920.000.000.000 Km

This result is an approximation, which will be refined as we study Earth further in the Atlas.

#### We Are All Stardust

Planets form from clouds of dust, just like stars (<htcite0>).

At the beginning of this process, the amount of dust particles is very small. As the cloud collapses, dust grains move closer and collide, forming larger clusters known as planetesimals (<htcite1>; <htcite2>; <htcite3>).

#### Planet Growth

These planetesimals continue to collide with other particles, giving rise to an even larger structure known as a protoplanet.

Over time, the protoplanet accumulates more material and eventually reaches the stage of a fully formed planet (<htcite4>).

source.text: Leinhardt, Zoe M., and Derek C. Richardson.

text.text:
#### What Is a Planet?

Today, there is broad consensus on how planets form.
However, the definition of a planet has been updated in recent years: to be considered a planet, an object must be massive enough to become spherical due to its own gravity, orbit a star, and clear its orbital path of other nearby objects (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

#### Applying the Scientific Method

Knowledge about the formation of planets is relatively recent. Before <htdate0>, it was believed that planets could not form during the early stages of the universe.

However, measurements taken by the Hubble Telescope showed that planets were already forming during the first phases of cosmic history.

This possibly occurred because the disks that give rise to planets lasted longer in the early universe, creating the necessary conditions for their formation (<htcite2>).

This discovery reinforces the idea that, in science, knowledge is constantly being updated and expanded.

### Location

After studying what the data shows us about the formation of the universe, stars, and planets, we can begin to talk about the regions of our planet.

But to do this, we must know how to locate ourselves on it.

Reflection: Where am I?

How do you locate yourself on planet Earth?

There are many answers to this reflection.

If your answer was “using maps, my phone, street names,” they are all correct—but there is something more we can explore. And that is exactly what we will begin to do in the upcoming texts of the *Atlas*.

### The History of a Theorem

The graph in this section is a visual proof—a mathematical argument that demonstrates the proposed concept is real (<htcite0>)—of the Pythagorean Theorem.

#### Where is it?

Have you ever asked yourself the following question?

Reflection: Pythagorean Theorem

Why do I need to learn the Pythagorean Theorem?

Nowadays, the Pythagorean Theorem is used daily by many professionals, often without people's knowledge. In this section, we make its use more visible to answer this reflection.

#### The Discovery

What we call the Pythagorean Theorem could not have been given that name when it was first discovered.

We will follow Dr. Daniel F. Mansfield, who uses the term "triple diagonal" to refer to the relationship between numbers that follow the same rule attributed to Pythagoras in ancient Babylonian texts, written in sexagesimal positional notation (<htcite0>).

The reasons for this are that Pythagoras could not have discovered something before he was born. Furthermore, despite the similarity between the values on the *Plimpton 322* tablet and the values obtained through trigonometry, it cannot be stated that the Babylonians used trigonometry in the same way as the Greeks and as we know it today. However, knowledge of the right triangle among the Babylonians is proven by the artifact *Si. 427*, housed in the Istanbul Archaeological Museum (<htcite1>).

Besides the Babylonians, there are also records of the relationship between the values of a right triangle in India (<htcite2>).

#### The Pythagorean Theorem

The version of the theorem we know today comes from Ancient Greece (<htcite0>; <htcite1>), more than a millennium after the Babylonian inscriptions. The Greek philosopher and mathematician Pythagoras is said to have reached the same conclusion, either through contact with this knowledge from other cultures or through his own studies. It is this version that we know in detail.

#### The Multiplication Table and the Triangle

As we advance in our studies, some information goes unnoticed, such as the fact that when we draw the multiplication table in a chart format, we can visualize it as a right triangle.

For more details on the multiplication table and right triangles, we suggest studying Chapter 4 of the *First Steps* of **History Tracers** (<htcite0>). Details about triangles are presented in the text that teaches the multiplication table for three (<htcite1>).

#### The Right Triangle

In the chart for this section, we have a right triangle (<htcite0>) centered on squares. To form this triangle, we used squares that, in the end, compose a larger square.

In this chart, we added 16 squares on the base, which we will call a **leg**. On the side opposite the angle theta (θ) (<htcite1>), we placed 9 squares, with one end connected to the endpoint of the square of value 4; we will also call this side a **leg**. Finally, we connected the points of the squares of value 1, forming a total of 25 squares, which we will call the **hypotenuse**.

We observe that the total number of squares on each side (9, 16, and 25) corresponds to the product of the length of each line by itself. That is, the total value of the geometric squares is given by the product of the size of each side by itself:

  • 9 = 3 x 3
  • 16 = 4 x 4
  • 25 = 5 x 5

Calculation 1: Sides of the triangle expressed in squares.

Reflection: This reminds me of...

Observe Calculation 1.

Can you create a mathematical relationship for the results of Calculation 1?

We can observe that by adding the squares of the legs, the result will be the square of the hypotenuse:/p>

  • 25 = 9 + 16

Calculation 2: Sum of the squares of the legs equals the square of the hypotenuse.

This result is known as the Pythagorean Theorem and we express it with *Formula 1*:

a2 + b2 = c 2

Formula 1: Pythagorean Theorem, where a is the adjacent leg, b is the opposite leg, and c is the hypotenuse.
Chart 1: Circle with a radius of 1 containing a right triangle.

### The Theorem and the Circle

Circles and lines have some common elements, but these can often go unnoticed. Something similar happens when we compare a plane and space. Therefore, before we continue, let's reflect:

Reflection: Pythagoras in an Atlas?

A right triangle is a flat, two-dimensional figure, while an atlas shows images of an ellipsoidal planet—a sphere with flattened extremes (; ).

How is it possible to use the Pythagorean theorem on our planet to locate ourselves?

#### Drawing a Circle

Nowadays, there are tools that allow us to draw circles, but we will use a method that makes explicit everything we need to understand it:

Practice 1: My Circle

Take a piece of string, a pencil, or any object that can stay straight. In this exercise, we will assume you selected a string.

1. Hold one end of the string firmly with one hand and stretch the rest of it with the other, keeping it stretched horizontally.
2. Now, rotate the stretched string counterclockwise around your fixed hand.

The string (or extended object) you used to make the circle, always kept at the same distance from the origin (called **O** in **Chart 1**), is known as the **radius** (<htcite0>). In the same **Chart 1**, we have highlighted only two lines towards the origin **O** and named them **c**.

#### The Triangle in the Circle

When we draw two lines **c** from the origin **O**, we create an angle between them, which we call **theta (θ)**.

Now, to form a triangle, we draw a vertical line from the end of the slanted line (point **P**) which we call **b**.

Reflection: I've Seen This Before

The radius c of the circle is a constant. And, looking back at the previous topic in the Atlas, we can associate it with the hypotenuse of the right triangle.

As a consequence of this association, the sides a and b of the triangle are the legs (or catheti).

After finding the triangle inside the circle, does this change in the legs remind you of anything else?

#### Angles and Multiplication

Moving away from the origin is something we study from our earliest years, but it is introduced gradually.

Observe the multiplication tables from 0 to 9 plotted with their results connected in **Chart 2**:
Chart 2: Points from the zero to nine multiplication tables connected, forming lines. Chart created with the Chart JS library.

Practice 2: Rotating

Let's perform the same rotation we did with the string, but using Chart 2

1. Click on the line names at the top of Chart 2; they are called legends. This will cause the lines to be hidden.
2. Now, starting from the Table of 0 up to the Table of 9, click on each legend again, observing what happens.

As you can see, as we multiply the same number by larger numbers, we are moving away from the horizontal. Since the radius was moved away from the horizontal in different practices, in all of them we were implicitly multiplying (<htcite0>).

#### Locating Ourselves

Finally, we can begin to locate ourselves on a circle, or on the surface of a planet, using the right triangle.

Note that in **Chart 1** , we have point **P**, which is the meeting point between the radius **c** (the hypotenuse) and the vertical line **b** (the leg opposite angle θ). Furthermore, at the other end of the vertical line, we also have point **Q**, which is the meeting point between legs **a** and **b**.

We can conclude, therefore, that all the elements (legs, angle, and hypotenuse) of the right triangle are directly linked to positions on the surface of a circle or a sphere.

In the next texts of the *Atlas*, we will explore this connection in more detail.
Chart 1: Circle with a radius of 1 containing a right triangle.

#### Trigonometry (Cosine)

In the previous text, we explored how to draw a right triangle and saw that, through the legs of the triangle or the hypotenuse, from the center we could reach any point **P** located on the circle.

In addition to the paths via the triangle, we also learned that, as a ray moves away from the horizontal line, we create an angle theta (θ) that we have not yet explored. This fact leads us to a reflection.

Reflection: How can I help you?

Knowing that the angle theta (θ) represents the opening of the ray, which in turn is related to the hypotenuse of the right triangle.

How can we connect this angle to the legs?

#### Trigonometry

Before establishing the relationship between the angle, the legs, and the hypotenuse, it is necessary to observe exactly what happens when the ray (the hypotenuse of the right triangle) rotates to create the circle, so that we can obtain relationships that accurately reproduce what we are observing.

Let's make a list of everything we need to reproduce in the relationships:
1. The horizontal leg **a** has its greatest length when the rotating ray is in the horizontal position. Meanwhile, the vertical leg **b** has its greatest length when the ray is in the vertical positions.
2. The angle theta (θ) increases from the horizontal, counterclockwise (from right to left).
3. Regarding the smallest length of the horizontal and vertical legs, this occurs precisely when the other leg is at its maximum value. That is: the horizontal leg **a** has its smallest size when the vertical leg **b** has its greatest value, and vice versa.
4. For all the described scenarios, the ray (the hypotenuse) always has a single length. The horizontal and vertical legs reach their maximum values when they equal the length of the ray.

The detailed study of these relationships is known as trigonometry (<htcite0>). This study is done through trigonometric functions, which we introduce next.

#### Cosine

### Where are we on a disk?

#### Walking

When we are walking down a straight street, we can locate ourselves starting from a street corner. For example, if that street is divided into blocks and each block is 50 meters, we will know that after walking 4 blocks, we will have traveled 200 meters from the corner where we began our walk (50 × 4 = 200) (<htcite0>).

What we have just described is a measurement in one dimension, meaning we need only one value to obtain the result and describe its measure (<htcite1>).

Looking at **Graph 1** in this section, we can see that if we want to know the distance between points **O** and **Q** (which we will represent from now on as **OQ**), we will be able to perform this measurement precisely because we are talking about a horizontal line, which we will call the **x-axis**.

#### The x-axis

When studying the cosine function, we learned that the length of leg a corresponds to the multiplication of the radius of the circle by the cosine of theta (c × cos(θ)). This happens because leg **a** represents the projection of radius **c** onto the adjacent leg (<htcite2>).

In **Graph 2**, we represent this projection again when there is an angle theta (θ) between the radius and the **eje x**.

#### The Y-axis

Let's reflect before proceeding.

Reflection: What about upward?

Could what we wrote about a horizontal path be applied to a vertical axis?
To answer this reflection, let's imagine that after walking 200 meters in one direction, as at the beginning of the text, you turned onto another street and walked another 200 meters.

Reflection: 200 that way, 200 this way...

Ignore houses, trees, people, and animals, and focus only on the distance of 200 meters in a straight line.

When walking 200 meters on any straight street, are you walking the same distance?

Possibly, in your reflection, you must have observed that the distance of 200 meters is the same on one street as on the other. That is, in both cases we are on a straight line, and regardless of the direction we walk, we end up covering the same 200 meters.

Now, we can return to the differences. By following a straight street and then turning onto another street and walking a bit more, we are following different paths, despite performing exactly the same type of movement.

Therefore, we will use what we learned in the text about sines to project the radius of the circle onto the vertical (<htcite0>), as shown in **Graph 3**:
Graph 3: Angle theta (θ) between the hypotenuse and the horizontal, with the opposite leg visible.

Notice that in **Graph 3**, we highlight leg **b**, which is related to the projection of the radius onto the vertical. From the previous text, we know that walking in the vertical direction is equivalent to multiplying the sine of theta by the radius of the circle to obtain the projection (c × sin(θ)) (<htcite0>).

#### Axes Together

As we have seen, the **axis x and y** are independent of each other, meaning that measurements in one direction do not necessarily depend on the other. Therefore, to determine the position of point **P** in **Graph 1**, we can indicate how far we walked from the origin to **Q** on the **x-axis** (**OQ**), and then how far we walked to point **P** along the **y-axis**, as follows:

These data lead us to conclude that we cannot use a horizontal projection to represent the vertical path. In other words, these are independent paths, which leads us to conclude that two measurements —or two dimensions (<htcite0>)— are needed to describe the path.

P = (x, y)

Mansfield called the *"diagonal triple"* (<htcite0>). Centuries later, this relationship became known as the Pythagorean Theorem, demonstrated in **Formula 2**:

a2 + b2 = c 2

To make clearer what we are studying, let's rename the legs according to the distances traveled:

(horizontal path)2 + (vertical path)2 = (diagonal path) 2

Formula 3: Description of paths.

As we saw in previous texts and in this text, the so-called **paths** are projections known as **legs**, while the diagonal is known as the **hypotenuse**. The horizontal leg is projected using the cosine of the angle, while the vertical leg is projected using the sine of the angle (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). Therefore, we can rewrite **Formula 3** as:

#### Conclusion

In this text, we saw that there are different ways to express a traveled path. Regardless of the approach used, the horizontal and vertical displacements are treated independently, although both represent the total distance traveled.

Furthermore, we observed, through the Pythagorean Theorem, that the relationships between the projections of the hypotenuse onto its legs can also be described using the cosine and sine of the angle formed between the hypotenuse and the horizontal.

Where are we on a sphere?

In the previous section, we extracted a flat disc from a sphere and learned to position ourselves on it. Now, let’s try a practical exercise:

Creating a Sphere

Draw a circle on a sheet of paper; you can use a plate as a guide, tracing around it with a pencil. Then, cut out the circle. Place it in front of you horizontally, and spin it a few times toward your feet.

By spinning the circle, we representing a sphere, similar to our planet, as shown in the image in this section. This exercise also highlights the need to define an additional variable to locate ourselves beyond a flat disc. This extra variable, represented by the Greek letter phi (ϕ), covers values between 0 and π radians, or 0 to 180 degrees. Introducing Phi (ϕ) transitions us from polar coordinates to spherical coordinates

Surface Coordinates

The figure in this section shows the intersection of the Equator parallel and the Greenwich Meridian, marked as point O. This serves as the reference point for all measurements of latitude and longitude.

The origin

To determine our position on Earth's surface, we initially use the angular coordinates theta (θ) and phi (ϕ). However, in everyday terminology, these coordinates are known by different names: theta (θ) corresponds to longitude, and phi (ϕ) is referred to as colatitude. In geographic contexts, we also use a measure called latitude (δ), which indicates position relative to the Equator. The relationship between latitude and colatitude is defined by the formula: ϕ = 90° - δ. This is just one of the simplifications we will explore further

Longitude

In mathematics, longitude (θ) s expressed in values ranging from 0 to 2π radians or 0 to 360 degrees. When applied to geographic coordinates, the Earth is divided into two regions of 180 degrees each. The dividing line between these regions is the Greenwich Meridian line, established arbitrarily in as zero degrees at the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, England. Positions east of Greenwich are measured as X degrees East, and positions to the west as X degrees West

Latitude

Latitude (ϕ) is represented mathematically with values ranging from 0 to π/2 radians or from 0 to 180 degrees. In geographic terms, Earth is divided into two 90 degrees regions: the Northern Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere. In mathematics, however, positions south of the Equator are represented with negative values. Unlike longitude, which is measured from a prime meridian, latitude is measured from the Equator — an imaginary line dividing the planet into northern and southern halves. Positions north of the Equator are noted as "X degrees North", and those south as "X degrees South"

Understanding Gravity

In the previous text, we mentioned gravity when defining a planet, but we didn’t explain the concept in detail. This section expands on that idea.

The Space-time

For a long time, we understood space, where we move, and time, which records the sequence of events, as absolute and separate dimensions. As a result, we believed that time was the same for everyone, whether it was a person reading this text, someone traveling in a car, or even an astronaut on a journey to the Moon

This understanding began to change in <htdate0>, when Albert Einstein proposed that space and time are relative, depending on the observer's motion. Although this idea may seem strange at first, it is not noticeable in our daily lives because we move at relatively slow speeds. However, numerous experiments have confirmed the accuracy of this theory, allowing us to explain phenomena like Mercury's orbit

In <htdate0>, Einstein introduced a more comprehensive theory—the General Theory of Relativity—which resolved the issue of Mercury's orbit along with other cosmological mysteries. This theory presents two essential concepts for our study

• The universe can be described by a four-dimensional structure known as space-time, which combines the three spatial coordinates (height, width, and depth) with time, forming a continuous four-dimensional fabric.
  • In space-time, the presence of mass curves this structure; in other words, objects with mass distort space-time around them.

The planet and space-time

When a planet forms, it tends to acquire a spherical or near-spherical shape, like an ellipsoid. In doing so, it curves the space-time, as illustrated in this section’s figure. The effect of moving within this curved space-time is what we call gravity. John Wheeler famously explained it this way: "Matter tells space-time how to curve, and space-time tells matter how to move". A clear example of this phenomenon is our planet’s orbit around the Sun, caused by the curvature that the Sun’s mass creates in space-time

source.text: Hu, X., Shum, C.K. & Bevis, M.

Is Gravity Really a Force?

We began by describing gravity based on our current understanding, but this has not always been the case. In the past, gravity was seen as a force, and using this perspective helps explain certain phenomena on Earth, as we will explore

Konstantino Adamopoulos et al. highlight that various systems in our bodies can be affected by the strength of the gravitational field. Additionally, they discuss how gravity has influenced species evolution, using as an example the arrangement of internal organs in aquatic snakes versus tree-climbing snakes

On the other hand, it’s also possible to consider that there is no "gravity force" per se, and that other forces might produce similar effects. For instance, the acceleration measured on the Earth’s surface is not constant and partly results from internal Earth pressure, leading us to observe an acceleration that could be associated with a force stemming from this internal pressure

source.text: Hu, X., Shum, C.K. & Bevis, M.

Gravity as a Central Force

When we talk about gravity as a force in Newton’s model, we often simplify things, and these simplifications can sometimes lead to misunderstandings. For example, it’s common to hear that the "gravitational force" pulls objects "downward", which is imprecise and might cause some people to think of Earth as flat. The "gravitational force" is a central force that attracts objects toward Earth’s center

Finally, we’d like to use this gravitational model to address a question I’ve often received: "If the Earth isn’t flat, why don’t we fall off it in certain places?" According to Newton’s gravitational model, escaping Earth’s surface requires moving at a very high speed. Without reaching this speed, known as escape velocity, gravity keeps us grounded on Earth
We will discuss the concept of a flat Earth in more detail later.

Earth: A "Living" Planet

When discussing maps, it is essential to consider geological time, as continents have not always existed in their present form. Besides the continental landmasses, we must also account for tectonic plate movements, which play a major role in the formation and transformation of visible land structures

text.text: Before continents settled into their current configuration, Earth went through periods dominated by supercontinents. One example is Gondwana, a massive landmass that included what are now South America (Abya Yala), Africa, India, Australia, and Antarctica. This supercontinent encompassed the region from which our species would later emerge: Africa

Over millions of years, Gondwana joined with other landmasses to form the supercontinent Pangea. Eventually, Pangea began to break apart due to tectonic plate movement, a process that, according to the most widely accepted geological models, led to the formation of the continents as we know them today

### Bantu Expansion

When studying the languages spoken on the African continent, it is noteworthy that linguistic diversity, despite the vast territorial expanse, is lower compared to that of the Americas (*Abya Yala*) and Asia (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

This fact leads us to conclude that there was an expansion of the Bantu people into different regions of Africa (<htcite2>).

#### Expansion Models

The figure in this section presents two possible hypotheses for the Bantu migration (<htcite3>; <htcite4>):
- **Early-split**: the Bantu migration occurs in two directions—east and west of the African continent.
- **Late-split**: in this hypothesis, the Bantu dispersal would have occurred only after crossing the rainforests.

Since sciences are developed through questioning and evidence, not just theories, the foundations supporting this model are not considered immutable. This fact led Doctor Igor Yanovich to raise some points, which we address next (<htcite5>).

#### A Linguistic Perspective

One of the first points addressed by Igor Yanovich regarding the Bantu languages concerns their current classification. He draws attention to the fact that the 540 currently classified languages follow a classificatory system that should not be understood as a definitive scientific consensus (<htcite6>; <htcite7>).

source.text: Pakendorf, B., de Filippo, C., & Bostoen, K.

text.text:
Another point highlighted by Igor Yanovich is related to the possible origin of the Bantu languages' expansion from Cameroon, between approximately <htdate0> and <htdate1>, a hypothesis that lacks sufficient data for robust support (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>).

Regarding the tree that would connect the Bantu languages, Igor Yanovich raised points that require deeper analysis, such as the small amount of data analyzed and the fact that the connection between the languages may not be unidirectional, but could actually be convergent, as occurs in some genealogical analyses (<htcite3>).

#### Archaeology

Archaeological research in Africa, especially in the central region, is still in its early stages, with few sites having been explored. Furthermore, the African soil does not favor the preservation of artifacts over millennia. As a consequence, there is no clear evidence regarding the complete evolution of pottery artifacts (<htcite4>).

Reflection: On Trade

What is needed to conduct trade between two people? Or even, what is needed to conduct trade between two peoples?

#### Trade Data

If, in your response to the reflection, you thought that money and goods should be present for trade to occur, this is a good starting point.

However, regarding money, as Dr. Bing Zhao rightly points out, some care must be taken. One of the explanations given by Dr. Zhao is the fact that Chinese copper coins cannot be studied as chronological markers, since coins minted in one dynasty could continue to be used in foreign trade in later dynasties (<htcite0>). Despite this point of caution when studying coins, there are other aspects mentioned in the article that need to be emphasized (<htcite1>):
- Chinese coins could have been used as a secondary currency in a global trade.
- The coins could represent the presence of Austronesians — peoples from East Asia, Oceania, and Madagascar who share a common maritime ancestry — in the Indian Ocean.

Regarding products, the Chinese ceramics that appear in East Africa correspond to four distinct periods between <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

#### How did they calculate?

We have seen so far that in East Africa, there was trade and that Chinese coins were present. Furthermore, we know that the profile of the goods changed over time, indicating adaptations by the local population to the goods and changes in their needs (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). This leads us to a reflection:

Reflection: How ....?

The goods changed in size and coins were present. On the other hand, we have no known written records from the Shona, but we know they spoke a language originating from a migration that began between approximately and (; ; ).

The lack of texts from one side apparently did not prevent trade. Did the Shona really not develop writing, or do we simply not know about it?

To make payments or even barter, it is necessary to know how to evaluate something and assign it a value. Since counting systems have existed in Africa for over 30,000 years (), could the Shona have used their own counting system to define values?

Assuming they had a numerical system, could it also have included the concept of zero?

### Mesoamerica: The Beginning

Maps like those presented in the section *Continent: Africa* reflect historical divisions that have shaped the borders we recognize today. However, not all maps created by humans are intended to define borders. An example is the map in this section, which highlights a region known as Mesoamerica. This concept was not created by the Indigenous peoples of the region but was defined centuries later by anthropologist Paul Kirchhoff. He used this term to group cultures that shared common characteristics within a specific geographical area

### America: Mesoamerica (Different Frontiers)

In the following pages of her work, Winifred Creamer analyzes other studies that, by considering additional factors such as technological systems, redefine and expand the original boundaries of Mesoamerica proposed by Paul Kirchhoff. Europe: Visigoths

The exact origin of the Goths is uncertain, as they left no early written records. Some scholars suggest they may have originated in what is now Poland. There is also debate on whether the Goths constituted a distinct ethnic group; some researchers believe they may have been a confederation of various tribes

The Visigoths, also known as the "Western Goths",  split from the Ostrogoths in the 4th century. One of the most significant events in their history is the invasion and sack of Rome in <htdate0>, led by their king Alaric I, who died shortly afterward. His successor, Ataulf, expanded Visigothic influence, conquering parts of Gaul and founding the Visigothic Kingdom there

After establishing a presence in Gaul, the Visigoths continued their expansion into the Iberian Peninsula around <htdate0>. By <htdate1>, they controlled the region shown in green on the map in this section

The Visigothic kingdom ultimately fell in <htdate0>. Although traditionally described as a Muslim "invasion", contemporary analysis suggests a more complex situation. The councils held in Visigothic territory reveal significant oppression toward women, Jews, and Arian Christians, leading parts of the population to welcome Muslim intervention

The Size of the Earth

The understanding that the Earth is spherical dates back thousands of years. The ancient Greeks reached this conclusion by observing how ship masts disappeared over the horizon and by noting the Earth’s shadow cast on the Moon during lunar eclipses. However, these observations did not provide a precise measurement of the Earth’s roundness. The first confirmed measurement was made around by Eratosthenes. On the summer solstice, he observed that in the city of Syene, the Sun’s rays reached straight to the bottom of a well, while in Alexandria, a pole cast a shadow pointing south. By knowing the properties of circles and the distance between Alexandria and Syene, Eratosthenes calculated the Earth’s circumference to be around 40,000 kilometers

The Earth's Diameter

More than 1,000 years later, Eratosthenes' calculations were confirmed under the authority of an Abbasid Caliph. A more precise measurement of the Earth’s meridians, and consequently of its radius, was carried out later by Al-Biruni. For his measurements, Al-Biruni was in Kath during a lunar eclipse, recording the event’s timing, while his colleague Abu’l-Wafa made observations in Baghdad. Additionally, Al-Biruni used the distances of caravan routes to determine the difference in longitude between Baghdad and Ghazni. With this data, he estimated the Earth’s radius to be approximately 6,371 kilometers, corresponding to an angle of 24 degrees at a latitude of 33 degrees north—a value that matches the Earth's average radius

Our Coordinates

Before pinpointing our location on Earth, let’s consider a question:

>Reflection: Are we using the correct number of variables?

Could we be oversimplifying by using only longitude (θ) and latitude (δ) to locate ourselves on the Earth's surface?

Simplification

When we use only latitude and longitude to determine our location, we are indeed simplifying. This approach assumes a constant average Earth radius, estimated at 6,371 kilometers (Km) (or 6,371,000 meters (m))

To better understand this simplification, let’s look at an example. By assuming a constant Earth radius, we don’t remove it from our calculations; rather, we omit it in the final representation of coordinates. This allows us to express the locations of cities like Tokyo and Montevideo with latitude and longitude alone

• Tokyo: (35,6764° Norte, 139,6500° Leste)
  • Montevideo: (34,9055° Sul, 56,1851° Oeste)

All variables

To express coordinates more precisely, it’s essential to use the same unit of measurement for all coordinates. On the Earth's surface, when we work with angles, we can simplify calculations by omitting the Earth’s radius. However, for three-dimensional accuracy, we need to include the radius and convert angle measurements from degrees to radians before continuing with calculations

• θ' = θ π180
  • ϕ = (90 - δ) π180

Next, we apply these converted angles in the formulas for spherical-to-Cartesian conversion, considering the radius r:
<center>(x, y, z) = (r cos(θ') sin(ϕ), r sin(θ') sin(ϕ) , r cos (ϕ))

• Tokyo: (-3944126.27, 3350784.05, 3715609.67)
  • Montevideo: (2907683.28, 4341002.95, -3645642.93)

With this three-dimensional representation, we achieve a complete and highly precise location.

text.text: The Myth of a Flat Earth

What is a Plane?

To answer this question, we can simplify the definition given by Eric W. Weisstein: a plane is a rigid, two-dimensional surface

The mathematical definition of a plane alone excludes the possibility of a flat Earth. As we’ve discussed, continents and oceans are not rigid surfaces; they are made of matter, which is part of the observable universe and has mass. This mass requires Earth to have a third dimension, making it impossible for Earth to be a perfectly flat surface

We can further confirm this by observing a lunar eclipse. In these events, the Moon is not partially covered by a flat shadow; instead, a curved shadow is projected onto its surface—something the ancient Greeks had already observed

The Origin of the Flat Earth Myth

The myth of a flat Earth is, in fact, a relatively recent idea that emerged in the 19th century, rooted in false narratives. Among these was the incorrect claim that Christopher Columbus "proved" the Earth was round and that Greek knowledge of Earth’s shape had been lost. In reality, Columbus and his contemporaries were primarily concerned with the logistical challenges of a long voyage, such as the availability of supplies, as it was already well-known that Earth’s circumference was around 40,000 kilometers

According to historian Jeffrey Burton Russell, before <htdate0>, Columbus "discovery" of a round Earth was mentioned only superficially in some schoolbooks. However, by the <htdate1>, this narrative had become widely accepted in educational texts. The idea that Greek knowledge of Earth’s shape was entirely forgotten is also tied to a false narrative suggesting a supposed conflict between science and religion

Map Projections

The fact that Earth is not flat does not mean we cannot represent it on a plane.

To create a map projection, we first need a scaled globe model of Earth. Using this model, we select a technique to transfer the spherical representation onto a two-dimensional surface, such as paper. The image in this section demonstrates the "Developable Surface", technique, which is used with projections like the Conic Projection with a Standard Parallel. However, this is just one of many available techniques. In the work by the National Council of Educational Research and Training, Lambert’s projection and Mercator’s projection are also discussed; these are widely used for creating world maps

Human Migration

Our species emerged somewhere in Africa between 350,000 and 200,000 years ago, according to fossil evidence. However, the migration out of Africa did not happen immediately. Around 70,000 to 50,000 years ago, Homo sapiens began migrating to different regions of Asia. Fossils also indicate another major migration between 45,000 and 35,000 years ago, moving towards the European continent and northeastern Asia

Regarding the arrival to the Americas (Abya Yala), current evidence suggests that the first humans arrived sometime between 30,000 and 22,000 years ago, likely through multiple migratory waves. Recent studies on the Mapuche people, for example, indicate at least two major migrations toward the southern regions of the continent

The description of human origins and their dispersion over millennia was traditionally based on written narratives, which, in the most optimistic estimates, projected only 177 generations since the ‘origin’ of our species. With advances in knowledge and DNA analysis techniques, we have gained a clearer understanding of our migrations, and today we can more accurately estimate that the number of human generations is around 8,000

Cradle of Civilization

Observing the humanity distribution, constructions around the planet, the geography and the relationship between people, we observe the idea that an unique cradle of civilization is not consistent with our current knowledge. Although the origin of specie in Africa is widely accepted, the hipotesis of all civilization arises from Mesopotamia looks like improbable. The Ancient Babylonian World Map

Our understanding of the world has evolved over time. In antiquity, people represented the "world" as their immediate surroundings, rather than as the planet Earth as we know it today. The image in this section shows the world as envisioned by the Babylonians. In the next section, we project this map onto a modern world map to facilitate comparison

Reflection: External Influences

As we began studying trigonometry, we noted measures like the famous "Pythagorean theorem" was already known by the Babylonians over a millennium before the Greeks. This fact raises the possibility that the Greeks either acquired this knowledge from other civilizations or independently arrived at the same conclusions more than a thousand years later (Mansfield, D. F.).

However, the exchange of knowledge is not limited to mathematics. Dr. Irving Finkel, in explaining the map featured in this section, also references a cuneiform text preserved in the British Museum. This text makes mention, among other things, of an Ark and its dimensions. Finkel points out a shared element between the map and this text: the word parsiktu, which denotes a unit of volume (Finkel, I, The British Museum ; Finkel, I, The Institute for the Study of Ancient Cultures, 50:06 - 56:11).

Additionally, Dr. Finkel notes that one of the mountains mentioned on the map is near a region called Urartu—located in present-day Armenia, Türkiye, and Iran—which corresponds to "Ararat" mentioned in the book of Genesis in the Hebrew text. Given the way the Pentateuch was composed, it is possible that Babylonian traditions influenced later Jewish narratives, as Dr. Finkel suggests (Finkel, I, The British Museum ; Finkel, I, The Institute for the Study of Ancient Cultures, 50:06 - 56:11 ; Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, Gênesis 8:4 ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia ; Davies, G. I.).

These archaeological discoveries demonstrate how stories and beliefs were exchanged among neighboring cultures and civilizations. Could it be possible, then, that these cultural influences extended even further, deeply shaping the traditions of distant peoples as they rewrote their own histories?

Rabbi Dr. Yitzchok Breitowitz, on the Jewish Learning Institute, reflects on the use of metaphor and allegory in sacred texts, noting how these elements may reflect historical events. Similarly, Dr. Abdul Karim Khan reminds us that concepts of creation and the world have emerged across different cultures, each with its own interpretations and symbolism
